newsitem.title: YUGOSLAVIA: Discount rate unch, banks' reserves up -Yugo cbank.
newsitem.headline: Discount rate unch, banks' reserves up -Yugo cbank.

text.p: The Yugoslav central bank kept its discount rate for September unchanged at 4.5 percent, or 68.15 percent a year, by raising banks' reserve requirements, central bank vice-governor Ratko Banovic said on Friday.
"We made no changes in the discount rate for September, but in order to keep it unchanged, we had to introduce a 10-percent reserve requirement for the banks," Banovic told Reuters.
According to Banovic, tampering with the reserve requirement was the only way to prevent the discount rate from rising. The discount rate was last cut to a monthly 4.5 percent in June.

The National Bank of Yugoslavia (NBY) sets its discount rate based on a basket of various parameters including inflation, interest rates on the open money market, expected monetary developments, credit demand, money supply and the rate on its short-term bonds sold on the Belgrade bourse.
The central bank was worried growing inflation would force it to adjust the discount rate. July monthly inflation jumped to 6.6 percent from 3.3 percent a month earlier.
But August took the pressure off when inflation slowed to 2.3 percent, according to figures released by the Statistics Office on Friday.
Banovic said the NBY will keep the discount rate as its key instrument for regulating market liquidity but the rate cannot be the only instrument used.

"The discount rate is a very subtle instrument, and in an economy like ours, where companies and banks are in a difficult situation, the discount rate cannot be the only instrument of regulating market liquidity," he said.
"By changing the discount rate we try to send signals both to banks and companies. Sometimes they understand, but sometimes they don't," he said.
At the beginning of 1996, the discount rate and the interest rate on the NBY's short-term bonds sold via the Belgrade bourse were at much higher levels.

"The end of every year is marked by surging liquidity among the banks, and we wanted to sop up surplus liquidity by attracting it to our short-term bonds (and) offering higher interest rates. And it worked," Banovic said.

"Our bonds are good instrument, they are a reliable investment with guaranteed payment of interest. Those bonds allowed us to keep monetary stability," he added. -- Gordana Filipovic, Belgrade newsroom, +381 11 222 4254
